awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Toric Geometry, Tropical Geometry, and Combinatorial Buildings
awd_abstract_narration:
This project involves research at the intersection of algebraic geometry and combinatorics. Algebraic geometry is the study of solution sets of polynomial equations called algebraic varieties. It has applications in many fields as diverse as high energy physics, coding, cryptography, and mathematical biology. Understanding how the shape of the solution set changes as the coefficients are varied is one of the oldest and central questions in the field. Such continuous deformations, which appear in all branches of algebraic geometry and its applications, are called algebraic families. An important example is the geometric Langlands program, which is concerned with understanding principal bundles on curves, a very special class of families. Bundles are also main players in gauge theory in high energy physics. Algebraic families are the central focus of this project. The research aims to introduce new methods to classify and compute with algebraic families. The project will provide research training opportunities for graduate students.

Toric varieties are a large class of varieties whose geometry is intimately connected with combinatorics of convex lattice polytopes. They play a central role in contemporary algebraic geometry. Tropical geometry, a relatively recent area of research, concerns study of piecewise linear geometry and has roots in convex optimization. Tropical geometry translates numerous questions in algebra and geometry into combinatorial and convex geometric questions that are often more tractable. The theory of buildings is an area of combinatorial geometry that has deep connections with topology and differential geometry. It aims to unravel hidden combinatorial geometric structures in matrix groups and related spaces. The topics of this research revolve around the common theme of studying families of algebraic varieties over a toric variety, or a toric family for short. The main insight is that the combinatorics needed to understand toric families comes from both tropical geometry and the theory of buildings. The approach followed in this project will lead to the development of new techniques in algebraic geometry and related fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit:

The purpose of this project is to explore connections between three important areas of of algebraic geometry, combinatorics, and group theory, continuous families of algebraic varieties, tropical geometry, and the theory of buildings. 

Families of spaces, in particular vector bundles and principal bundles, are essential objects in topology, all branches of geometry, and high energy physics. Tropical geometry is a form of geometry modelled on algebraic geometry using alternative algebraic operations.  Tropical spaces are polyhedral, and their combinatorics can be used to make problems in algebraic geometry tractable.  Buildings are discrete complexes used to study the structure of algebraic groups, and their appearance in this work acts as a bridge between tropical geometry and the geometry of bundles. 

One of the primary outcomes of this project is a collection of building-theoretic classification results for bundles on algebraic varieties equipped with a large torus action.  Principal bundles on toric varieties are shown to be classfied by piecewise-linear maps to spherical buidlings, vector bundles over toric schemes are shown to be classified by piecewise affine maps to affine buildings, and vector bundles on complexity-1 varieties are shown to be classified by globalized piecewise affine maps to buildings.  These advances are then used to prove combinatorial formulas for the characteristic classes of bundles and to relate bundles on toric varieties to the theory of valuations. Finally, this work opens the new topic of tropical vector bundles, which promises to considerably strengthen the connection between tropical geometry and classical algebraic geometry.  

As somewhat simpler spaces, bundles are also an effective laboratory for testing conjectures in geometry.  The combinatorial classifications developed as part of this project allow the discovery of new families of algebraic varietes which satisfy Fujita's freeness and ampleness conjectures. New families of Mori dream spaces with interesting connections to the theory of representation stability are also discovered and described. 

Broader Impacts:

Two PhD students trained and partially supported by this project, with two more PhD students are expected to graduate in 2025.  Part of this project also funded work on algebraic methods with applications to biology as part of one of these students dissertation. 

This project also supported three undergraduate research summer programs, and three year-long programs through the UK Math Lab.   In particular, 13 undegraduate research students participated in the project.  Many of these participants are first generation university students. 

In addition to coordinating undergraduate research, the UK Math Lab also runs community building programs in the UK Math Department, including reading groups, social events, and a weekly mathematical quilting group. These programs serve as a unofficial venue for students to share experiences and strategies for navigating professional mathematics.    The quilting group has produced five large quilts, and we are presently working to finish the sixth.  Pictured in the images are the completed Cayley table quilt for the group SL_2(F_3), and our work-in-progress on the Conway pinwheel tiling quilt.
